blog.name: incorrect-ironstrange
blog.title: Endgame is NOT Canon on This Blog
blog.description:
Repentant stony shipper.  Ironstrange and supremefamily content. Main blog @lucifers-favorite-child. Posts tagged #incorrect-ironstrange. Icon from @hello-shellhead. 
I write on AO3 as lucifersfavoritechild .
Throw money at me: http://ko-fi.com/V7V6IXJK.
Long live the irondick!
...
I guess this is a Peter and Stephen stan blog now.

summary:
Tony: Do you think I would make a good king?
Stephen: King of Jerking Off, maybe.

blog.name: tinydragontony
blog.title: TinyDragonTony
blog.description: This is a side blog dedicated to the frostrion fanfiction "Adventures of Tiny Dragon Tony and His Treasure (Loki)" found on AO3. Simply put, I don't have time to write full length fanfics so I want to compile a collection of snapshots into the lives of tiny dragon Tony and his ever sweet yet mischievous lover Loki. So, if that tickles your fancy, why not give us a follow? Or, better yet, follow us on AO3 for update notifications!

summary: Braided
title: Braided
body:
Tony sets his micro-screwdriver down and leans back to rub at his strained eyes.

     He’d been holed up in his lab working on this omni-tool prototype for three nearly sleepless days and the project is only now in entering the final stages of construction. The innerworkings of the machine, particularly the holographic interface, had proven to be far more intricate than he originally anticipated, but let it not be said that Anthony Edward Stark runs from a challenge! Though he was loath to admit it, it was probably Jarvis’s strict enforcement of his new “make Tony take mandatory breaks at least once every five hours, if not more, so he doesn’t implode” protocol that kept him somewhat sane. 

     It also helped that every time Jarvis forced him back into the real world there always seemed to be a plate of warm food and freshly brewed coffee waiting for him at the end of his workbench. He knew it was Loki’s doing and Tony smiled as he ate it, picturing Loki in their kitchen, apron tied snuggly around his trim waist and hair pulled back as he cooks, sending the plate and coffee down to the lab with a wave of his elegant hand before settling down to eat his own portion. Tony would then picture the same scene, Loki’s hair pulled back, apron tied around his waist, nothing else on underneath…(*coughcough* Ahem, impure thoughts). 

     Sometimes Tony would take his plate and mug upstairs to eat with him, and Loki would grin, a pleased flush coloring his cheeks; other times Loki would join him in his lab, two steaming plates of whatever delicacy he had prepared that day in hand, the smell enough to pull Tony out of his chair and to the loveseat situated in the corner where they shared their meal together, ankles hooked around one another. Today was a day like the latter.

     Tony stretches his arms above his head, sighing as satisfying pops ripple up his spine. He tilts his head side to side and swivels around in his chair, his heart stuttering when he spots Loki curled up on the loveseat, their empty dishes from lunch littering the end table behind him.

     Loki’s back is facing the room and his long legs are pulled up to his chest, one more so than the other, which leaves one of his feet dangling off the couch’s edge, and, when Tony stands to get a closer look, he can see that Loki’s face is smushed up against the throw pillow, his breathing soft and even. He smiles and kneels by Loki’s head, watching him for a moment before lifting a hand to tuck a stray curl behind Loki’s ear. He does it again, so captivated by the silkiness of Loki’s hair that he doesn’t notice he’s woken up.

     Loki lets him continue, a soft smile on his face as Tony gingerly reaches under his head to free the rest of his hair so he can comb his fingers through it with a reverent sigh. It isn’t long before Loki feels the tell-tale pulling, though it’s extremely gentle, of a braid being weaved into his hair. He hears Tony sigh again before fingers move against his scalp, the braid falling apart so Tony can start again. This routine plays out a few more times, enough so that Loki thinks Tony must just enjoy the repetitive motions, but he is far from complaining about the pleasure of having his hair played with.

     He’s so relaxed under Tony’s ministrations that he barely registers that Tony’s hands have dropped away until he feels Tony press a kiss to the back of his head.

     “You’re awake, aren’t you?” There’s amusement in his tone so Loki turns to face him, meeting Tony’s grin with one of his own.

     “I am.”

     Tony presses a soft kiss to his lips and Loki sighs as Tony pulls away, Tony’s grin now a smirk.

     “Let me take you out for dinner tonight.”

     “Mm, fine.”

     “You have to leave the braid in, though. I worked hard on it and it actually looks nice.” Tony caresses his cheek. “Very nice.”

     A blush blooms across his cheeks. “If that’s all it takes, I’ll do it.”

     Tony rewards him with another kiss before he jumps up and pulls Loki to his feet. The two of them head upstairs to get ready for their date, and when they’re late to the reservation slot Jarvis managed to squeeze in by over an hour due to some shower-time shenanigans, the restaurant made sure that table remained open for them, because who in their right mind would keep Tony Stark from showing his date a good time?

Today’s snapshot into the lives of Tony and Loki is based on art by @zwierzodudle, found here!: http://zwierzodudle.tumblr.com/post/184094001202/finally-had-some-time-so-i-turned-back-to-prompts


If you would like to read more snapshots of Tony and Loki’s adventures, find them on AO3!: https://archiveofourown.org/works/17533676/chapters/41312006

blog.name: ao3feed-tonystark
blog.title: Ao3-Feed: Tony Stark
blog.description: This blog is an automated list of the stories posted on Archive Of Our Own under the Tony Stark tag. The stories are automatically posted here from the AO3 RSS feed.

summary: shoot the breeze (this was a good thing)
title: shoot the breeze (this was a good thing)
body:
read it on the AO3 at http://bit.ly/2Zpogzw

by lovelywoords

The most important part of his skillset, Hawkeye had taught himself.

Words: 37250, Chapters: 1/1, Language: English

  • Fandoms: Marvel Cinematic Universe
  • Rating: Teen And Up Audiences
  • Warnings: Creator Chose Not To Use Archive Warnings, No Archive Warnings Apply
  • Categories: Gen
  • Characters: Clint Barton, Hawkeye, Steve Rogers, Tony Stark, Natasha Romanov (Marvel), Bruce Banner, Thor (Marvel), Laura Barton, Wanda Maximoff, Carol Danvers, Scott Lang, James Rhodes, Sam Wilson (Marvel), Guardians of the Galaxy Team, Peter Parker, James “Bucky” Barnes, T'Challa (Marvel), Shuri (Marvel), Stephen Strange, Pepper Potts, May Parker (Spider-Man), Jane Foster (Marvel), Thaddeus Ross, Michelle Jones, Vision (Marvel)
  • Relationships: Clint Barton/Laura Barton, Clint Barton & Tony Stark, Clint Barton & Steve Rogers, Clint Barton & Natasha Romanov, Clint Barton & Wanda Maximoff, Bruce Banner & Clint Barton, Clint Barton & Thor, Pepper Potts/Tony Stark, Bruce Banner/Natasha Romanov, Peter Parker & Tony Stark, James “Bucky” Barnes & Steve Rogers, Michelle Jones/Peter Parker, Wanda Maximoff/Vision, Steve Rogers & Tony Stark
  • Additional Tags: excessive threats of tableware destruction, tableware destruction

blog.description:
Father, trophy husband, retired Avenger. Ask away.

I check the tag "sarcastictonystark" and you can @tag me

Not currently accepting M!As Currently accepting compliments

Discord Join Link

summary: Realizing you’re not unstoppable and some things out there can kill you. It takes longer for some people than others.
body: Realizing you’re not unstoppable and some things out there can kill you. It takes longer for some people than others.

blog.name: itismarvelicious
blog.title: Qu'est-ce que j'irais faire au paradis ?
blog.description: French. 25. | Fixing Avengers: Endgame here. | I take prompts. | Pepperony mainly.

summary: You know, I think Tony and Pepper could've already been married in IW. But they were still planning the wedding, almost two...
body:
You know, I think Tony and Pepper could’ve already been married in IW. But they were still planning the wedding, almost two years after their engagement. If they weren’t married in IW, if they didn’t show us a wedding, it probably means they want to save it for the end of Endgame. I mean, if they had shown the wedding in IW, I would’ve thought “oh no. They’re showing us the good times now because it won’t end well for them.” After so many years hinting at a baby, talking about a wedding, they HAVE to show it to us at some point, or at least confirm it happened. So if we haven’t seen it by now, it means it’ll happen at the end.

Yep yep I’m fucking scared and full of doubts but it honestly wouldn’t make sense if they don’t go that way

reblog.comment:
You know, I think Tony and Pepper could’ve already been married in IW. But they were still planning the wedding, almost two years after their engagement. If they weren’t married in IW, if they didn’t show us a wedding, it probably means they want to save it for the end of Endgame. I mean, if they had shown the wedding in IW, I would’ve thought “oh no. They’re showing us the good times now because it won’t end well for them.” After so many years hinting at a baby, talking about a wedding, they HAVE to show it to us at some point, or at least confirm it happened. So if we haven’t seen it by now, it means it’ll happen at the end.

Yep yep I’m fucking scared and full of doubts but it honestly wouldn’t make sense if they don’t go that way

trail.content_raw:
You know, I think Tony and Pepper could’ve already been married in IW. But they were still planning the wedding, almost two years after their engagement. If they weren’t married in IW, if they didn’t show us a wedding, it probably means they want to save it for the end of Endgame. I mean, if they had shown the wedding in IW, I would’ve thought “oh no. They’re showing us the good times now because it won’t end well for them.” After so many years hinting at a baby, talking about a wedding, they HAVE to show it to us at some point, or at least confirm it happened. So if we haven’t seen it by now, it means it’ll happen at the end.

Yep yep I’m fucking scared and full of doubts but it honestly wouldn’t make sense if they don’t go that way
trail.content:
You know, I think Tony and Pepper could’ve already been married in IW. But they were still planning the wedding, almost two years after their engagement. If they weren’t married in IW, if they didn’t show us a wedding, it probably means they want to save it for the end of Endgame. I mean, if they had shown the wedding in IW, I would’ve thought “oh no. They’re showing us the good times now because it won’t end well for them.” After so many years hinting at a baby, talking about a wedding, they HAVE to show it to us at some point, or at least confirm it happened. So if we haven’t seen it by now, it means it’ll happen at the end.

Yep yep I’m fucking scared and full of doubts but it honestly wouldn’t make sense if they don’t go that way

summary: Tony: You know what I like about you? Stephen: What? Tony: Your so smart, your so pretty, your so powerful,your so pretty, you...
body:
Tony: You know what I like about you?

Stephen: What?

Tony: Your so smart, your so pretty, your so powerful,your so pretty, you get things done, your so pretty, you take things seriously, and did I mention that you are pretty?

Stephen: Yes, about twenty times now, but please continue.

tags: i cant help but to marvel
summary: Nobody: Tony Anti’s: Omg Tony is such an asshole he sells weapons Me: Girl...have you even watched the movies
question: Nobody: Tony Anti’s: Omg Tony is such an asshole he sells weapons Me: Girl...have you even watched the movies
answer: I genuinely feel that the majority of the people on this website who hate him haven’t actually formed that opinion based on anything they’ve personally observed but rather just absorbed the consensus of people on tumblr. I don’t care if people don’t like tony but that one talking point is just wild especially because they’ll turn around and say they like Captain America who is a real life symbol of American imperialism and the military industrial complex in whole ass life. It’s wild.

summary: Kamala riding with Tony ❤️
caption: Kamala riding with Tony ❤️

summary: of my own
title: of my own
body:
Nick Fury doesn’t much care for Tony Stark.

He’s loud. He’s flashy and bright and he takes up all the oxygen in the room. He gets under Nick’s skin in a way so few can. He cuts off people’s sentences and he acts like they should thank him for it. Nick sees him on TV and scoffs. He looks like Howard, in a way, and he acts like him too.

There’s something else there, though, but Nick can’t really put his finger on it. But whatever. Stark’s not his problem. Stark’s just another playboy, another billionaire wasting money on bombs and weapons.

Then Stark gets kidnapped. He goes missing for three months, and when he makes a triumphant return, with an explosion so big it shakes cities miles away, Nick Fury has a sick feeling in his stomach that he’s going to be seeing a lot more of Stark in the future.

Nick’s right. And Stark’s worse in person. He’s irritating and grating and nosy. He’s movement and motion, and he never truly shuts up. All in all, Fury’s not impressed.

Iron Man, on the other hand, is powerful. Iron Man is good. He’s something that Fury can respect, even if Stark’s the one underneath the mask.

And then aliens invade. 

Fury still doesn’t like Stark. He trusts him, more than he probably should. But when Stark flies a wormhole into space, Fury feels a strange tugging in his chest, and he thinks of the time when he thought that Tony was anything like Howard. It’s not true, just like he figures most of the assumptions people make about Tony Stark aren’t.

Stark isn’t like Romanoff or Banner or Thor or even Rogers. He wears his heart on his sleeve, and it’s right there, except Fury can’t see where it is. He asks Romanoff about it and she gives him a coy smile and tells him to ask Tony himself. He brushes the idea off.

And then the years go by. The initial something he’d noticed about Stark grows and grows, until Tony Stark and Tony are completely different people.

Tony Stark is still just as annoying as he ever was. He’s flippant and irresponsible, he’s smarmy and cocky all at once. But Tony? Tony’s kind. He’s smart, but not just in terms of numbers and computer code, he’s smart with people too. He gives, and he gives, and he gives, and he never expects anything in return.

So when Tony helps creates a murder bot hell bent on destroying the world, Nick isn’t exactly surprised. We are our own monsters, he supposes. And the fact that Ultron hates Tony the most? Well, he thinks, that’s it. That’s the thing he’s been missing the whole time.

Tony acts like everyone’s beneath him because he so desperately wants to believe that he’s not beneath them. Tony Stark helped created a robot that wanted to kill him. 

After that, Fury understands a hell of a lot more. 

And then, Tony confesses his darkest fears to Nick while wearing a plaid shirt in an old farmhouse. It’s humbling. And as Nick utters the words “Just an old man who cares very much about you,” he knows it’s true.

This is Tony Stark, stripped bare. This is Tony Stark, the same man who once told Fury that his only fear was spiders. This is Tony, emotional and worked up over his teammates dying. This is Tony, whose greatest fear is not dying, but rather, being responsible for his friends death. This is Tony, admitting this to Nick Fury, a man he once hated. 

And in that barn, Nick realizes that he might not hate Tony after all.

He still doesn’t like Tony, most of the time. Tony’s not the type of person he’d call if he were in trouble. His jokes rub Nick the wrong way, and he’s not Nick’s favorite.

But Tony’s not so bad. 

Nick kind of loves him. 

After all, you don’t always get to choose your family.

He’s loud. He’s flashy and bright and he takes up all the oxygen in the room. He gets under Nick’s skin in a way so few can. He cuts off people’s sentences and he acts like they should thank him for it. Nick sees him on TV and scoffs. He looks like Howard, in a way, and he acts like him too.

There’s something else there, though, but Nick can’t really put his finger on it. But whatever. Stark’s not his problem. Stark’s just another playboy, another billionaire wasting money on bombs and weapons.

Then Stark gets kidnapped. He goes missing for three months, and when he makes a triumphant return, with an explosion so big it shakes cities miles away, Nick Fury has a sick feeling in his stomach that he’s going to be seeing a lot more of Stark in the future.

Nick’s right. And Stark’s worse in person. He’s irritating and grating and nosy. He’s movement and motion, and he never truly shuts up. All in all, Fury’s not impressed.

Iron Man, on the other hand, is powerful. Iron Man is good. He’s something that Fury can respect, even if Stark’s the one underneath the mask.

And then aliens invade. 

Fury still doesn’t like Stark. He trusts him, more than he probably should. But when Stark flies a wormhole into space, Fury feels a strange tugging in his chest, and he thinks of the time when he thought that Tony was anything like Howard. It’s not true, just like he figures most of the assumptions people make about Tony Stark aren’t.

Stark isn’t like Romanoff or Banner or Thor or even Rogers. He wears his heart on his sleeve, and it’s right there, except Fury can’t see where it is. He asks Romanoff about it and she gives him a coy smile and tells him to ask Tony himself. He brushes the idea off.

And then the years go by. The initial something he’d noticed about Stark grows and grows, until Tony Stark and Tony are completely different people.

Tony Stark is still just as annoying as he ever was. He’s flippant and irresponsible, he’s smarmy and cocky all at once. But Tony? Tony’s kind. He’s smart, but not just in terms of numbers and computer code, he’s smart with people too. He gives, and he gives, and he gives, and he never expects anything in return.

So when Tony helps creates a murder bot hell bent on destroying the world, Nick isn’t exactly surprised. We are our own monsters, he supposes. And the fact that Ultron hates Tony the most? Well, he thinks, that’s it. That’s the thing he’s been missing the whole time.

Tony acts like everyone’s beneath him because he so desperately wants to believe that he’s not beneath them. Tony Stark helped created a robot that wanted to kill him. 

After that, Fury understands a hell of a lot more. 

And then, Tony confesses his darkest fears to Nick while wearing a plaid shirt in an old farmhouse. It’s humbling. And as Nick utters the words “Just an old man who cares very much about you,” he knows it’s true.

This is Tony Stark, stripped bare. This is Tony Stark, the same man who once told Fury that his only fear was spiders. This is Tony, emotional and worked up over his teammates dying. This is Tony, whose greatest fear is not dying, but rather, being responsible for his friends death. This is Tony, admitting this to Nick Fury, a man he once hated. 

And in that barn, Nick realizes that he might not hate Tony after all.

He still doesn’t like Tony, most of the time. Tony’s not the type of person he’d call if he were in trouble. His jokes rub Nick the wrong way, and he’s not Nick’s favorite.

But Tony’s not so bad. 

Nick kind of loves him. 

After all, you don’t always get to choose your family.
trail.content:
Nick Fury doesn’t much care for Tony Stark.

He’s loud. He’s flashy and bright and he takes up all the oxygen in the room. He gets under Nick’s skin in a way so few can. He cuts off people’s sentences and he acts like they should thank him for it. Nick sees him on TV and scoffs. He looks like Howard, in a way, and he acts like him too.

There’s something else there, though, but Nick can’t really put his finger on it. But whatever. Stark’s not his problem. Stark’s just another playboy, another billionaire wasting money on bombs and weapons.

Then Stark gets kidnapped. He goes missing for three months, and when he makes a triumphant return, with an explosion so big it shakes cities miles away, Nick Fury has a sick feeling in his stomach that he’s going to be seeing a lot more of Stark in the future.

Nick’s right. And Stark’s worse in person. He’s irritating and grating and nosy. He’s movement and motion, and he never truly shuts up. All in all, Fury’s not impressed.

Iron Man, on the other hand, is powerful. Iron Man is good. He’s something that Fury can respect, even if Stark’s the one underneath the mask.

And then aliens invade. 

Fury still doesn’t like Stark. He trusts him, more than he probably should. But when Stark flies a wormhole into space, Fury feels a strange tugging in his chest, and he thinks of the time when he thought that Tony was anything like Howard. It’s not true, just like he figures most of the assumptions people make about Tony Stark aren’t.

Stark isn’t like Romanoff or Banner or Thor or even Rogers. He wears his heart on his sleeve, and it’s right there, except Fury can’t see where it is. He asks Romanoff about it and she gives him a coy smile and tells him to ask Tony himself. He brushes the idea off.

And then the years go by. The initial something he’d noticed about Stark grows and grows, until Tony Stark and Tony are completely different people.

Tony Stark is still just as annoying as he ever was. He’s flippant and irresponsible, he’s smarmy and cocky all at once. But Tony? Tony’s kind. He’s smart, but not just in terms of numbers and computer code, he’s smart with people too. He gives, and he gives, and he gives, and he never expects anything in return.

So when Tony helps creates a murder bot hell bent on destroying the world, Nick isn’t exactly surprised. We are our own monsters, he supposes. And the fact that Ultron hates Tony the most? Well, he thinks, that’s it. That’s the thing he’s been missing the whole time.

Tony acts like everyone’s beneath him because he so desperately wants to believe that he’s not beneath them. Tony Stark helped created a robot that wanted to kill him. 

After that, Fury understands a hell of a lot more. 

And then, Tony confesses his darkest fears to Nick while wearing a plaid shirt in an old farmhouse. It’s humbling. And as Nick utters the words “Just an old man who cares very much about you,” he knows it’s true.

This is Tony Stark, stripped bare. This is Tony Stark, the same man who once told Fury that his only fear was spiders. This is Tony, emotional and worked up over his teammates dying. This is Tony, whose greatest fear is not dying, but rather, being responsible for his friends death. This is Tony, admitting this to Nick Fury, a man he once hated. 

And in that barn, Nick realizes that he might not hate Tony after all.

He still doesn’t like Tony, most of the time. Tony’s not the type of person he’d call if he were in trouble. His jokes rub Nick the wrong way, and he’s not Nick’s favorite.

But Tony’s not so bad. 

Nick kind of loves him. 

After all, you don’t always get to choose your family.
